channel.title: BBC News - Home
channel.description: The latest stories from the Home section of the BBC News web site.
channel.copyright: Copyright: (C) British Broadcasting Corporation, see http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/help/rss/4498287.stm for terms and conditions of reuse.

item.title: Skywatchers await solar eclipse
item.description: Millions of people could witness the best solar eclipse in years in northern Europe later, with large areas set to go into deep shadow.

item.title: Boko Haram 'defeated in a month'
item.description: Nigerian President Goodluck Jonathan tells the BBC that he hopes all territory seized by Islamist militants Boko Haram will be recaptured within a month.

item.title: Obama urges 'historic' Iran deal
item.description: US President Barack Obama tells the Iranian people a nuclear deal presents a rare chance to transform the two countries' relationship.

item.title: Greece 'to table new reform plan'
item.description: Greece has agreed to provide a new economic reform plan to secure the additional bailout funds required to prevent bankruptcy, EU leaders say.

item.title: Netanyahu denies two-state reversal
item.description: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu waters down a pre-election vow not to allow the establishment of a Palestinian state.

item.title: Ex-Australian PM Fraser dies at 84
item.description: Malcolm Fraser, who was Australian prime minister between 1975 and 1983, has died after a brief illness.

item.title: Thein Sein: Army to keep key role
item.description: Myanmar's army will continue to play a key role in the move towards greater democracy, President Thein Sein has told the BBC.

item.title: Nine arrested over Tunisia attack
item.description: Nine people are arrested over the gun attack at the Bardo museum in Tunis that left 23 people dead, including 20 foreign tourists.

item.title: NY chokehold evidence to stay secret
item.description: A New York judge refuses to make public the evidence a grand jury heard about the death of a black man held in a police "chokehold".

item.title: Arctic sea ice hits record low
item.description: Sea ice in the Arctic Ocean has fallen to the lowest recorded level for the winter season, according to US scientists.

item.title: End online humiliation says Lewinsky
item.description: The surprise guest of Ted 2015 gave one of the most well-received speeches, about online humiliation and cyberbullying.

item.title: VIDEO: Survivor on Pakistan school shooting
item.description: A Pakistani teenager who was flown to the UK for surgery after being shot by the Taliban, has been speaking to the BBC.

item.title: VIDEO: Why girls clothing is an issue in India
item.description: In Delhi, students from Ishani SKV Girls' School have been finding out why they cannot wear the clothes they want.

item.title: VIDEO: Police explode 20,000lb of fireworks
item.description: Police in Midland, Texas recently disposed of approximately 20,000lb (9071kg) worth of illegal fireworks in a controlled explosion.

item.title: VIDEO: One-minute World News
item.description: Watch the latest news summary from BBC World News. International news updated 24 hours a day.

item.title: VIDEO: Warning over looming solar eclipse
item.description: Astronomer Derrick Pitts of the Franklin Institute discusses the rarity - and danger - of the upcoming solar eclipse.

item.title: VIDEO: Poetry contest for construction workers
item.description: A group of migrant workers from Bangladesh are sharing poems of longing for family and home with enthusiasts in Singapore.

item.title: VIDEO: Five problems for Netanyahu - 60 secs
item.description: A one minute look at five issues Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu must tackle if he is returned to office.

item.title: VIDEO: Back to Ghana: Joy FM's DJ Black
item.description: 1Xtra presenter Twin B meets Joy FM as part of a project to take Ghanaian artists from the diaspora 'Back to Ghana' to create an original new track.

item.title: Cradle of 'Arab Spring' under threat
item.description: The BBC’s Aidan Lewis in Tunisia reports on the security challenges faced by the country in the wake of the deadly attack at the Bardo museum, which left 23 people dead.

item.title: Russians count cost a year after Crimea
item.description: A year after Russia took over Crimea, Richard Galpin in Moscow meets people hit by economic crisis and counts the cost for Russians.

item.title: Dark web spurs spying 'arms race'
item.description: Terrorists are turning to the dark web making it harder to track and tap their communications, says Frank Gardner

item.title: Netanyahu win gives Obama a headache
item.description: Benjamin Netanyahu's visit to America was a headache for the Obama administration's stance on Iran negotiations, PJ Crowley writes, but his election victory could be a longer malady for US hopes for the Israel-Palestinian peace process.

item.title: What should the UK do about foreign aid?
item.description: The UK is about to agree legislation committing it to ringfencing 0.7% of gross national income to international development spending. Prof Henrietta Moore on the way forward.

item.title: VIDEO: Solar eclipse: 90 second explainer
item.description: BBC News explains Friday's rare celestial event and how you can observe it safely - in 90 seconds.

item.title: VIDEO: China-Japan talks: Facts in 60 seconds
item.description: Awkward handshakes and territorial rows - the background to the China-Japan talks in less than 60 seconds.

item.title: Why can't they make a flushable wipe?
item.description: The number of wet wipes littering UK beaches has risen by 50%.

item.title: Belgian minister in 'black face' row
item.description: Belgian Foreign Minister Didier Reynders draws sharp criticism for having his face painted black during a traditional festival in Brussels.

item.title: Zayn Malik leaves One Direction tour
item.description: The singer leaves One Direction's tour of Asia after being signed off by management with stress.

item.title: Ryanair abandons US flight plans
item.description: Budget airline Ryanair abandons plans to operate transatlantic flights, just days after it said its board had approved the measure.

item.title: Asian shares dip on strong US dollar
item.description: Asian stocks are mostly lower after the US dollar recoups most of its losses following the Federal Reserve meeting on Wednesday.

item.title: Tag Heuer to make Android Wear watch
item.description: Swiss watchmaker Tag Heuer partners with top tech firms to build an Android Wear-powered smartwatch.

item.title: US approves Amazon drone trial
item.description: The US Federal Aviation Administration approves Amazon's plans to begin testing drones for online deliveries.

item.title: Clarkson 'fracas' report due next week
item.description: The BBC's report into Top Gear host Jeremy Clarkson's "fracas" with a producer is to be handed over to the director general next week.

item.title: Actress Minnelli returns to rehab
item.description: Liza Minnelli is admitted to a drug and alcohol rehabilitation unit for treatment of substance abuse.

item.title: Online farm payment system ditched
item.description: A multi-million pound government IT system to process EU subsidy payments for farmers has been largely abandoned following "performance problems".

item.title: Extinction threat to Europe's bees
item.description: Many of Europe's native wild bees are threatened with extinction, according to the first comprehensive assessment of risks.

item.title: 'Ebola-proof' tablet device developed
item.description: A tablet device that can withstand being doused in chlorine has been developed to help doctors caring for patients with Ebola.

item.title: Blood test 'could cut antibiotics'
item.description: A new prototype blood test can help doctors tease out whether an infection is caused by bacteria or a virus within two hours, research suggests.

item.title: Pietersen motivated by Ashes return
item.description: Kevin Pietersen wants a face-to-face meeting with new England cricket chief Colin Graves as he targets an Ashes comeback.

item.title: Exit not defence's fault - Martinez
item.description: Roberto Martinez highlights quality finishing rather than poor defending in Everton's Europa League exit to Dynamo Kiev.

item.title: Meeting the Houthis - and their enemies
item.description: Safa AlAhmad travelled across Yemen to talk to the Houthis who have taken over the capital - and to their opponents from al-Qaeda.

item.title: The country where you can choose your tax rate
item.description: Mali currently has two rates of income tax - 30%... or 3%. Quite a difference. So the BBC's Alex Duval Smith was surprised to be asked to choose.

item.title: Clapton's Layla in ancient Sanskrit
item.description: Indian music lovers are revelling in a Sanskrit language version of Eric Clapton's old favourite, Layla.

item.title: Gold found in socks leads to court
item.description: A Russian man is found guilty of keeping a hoard of gold he found in some socks by the roadside.

item.title: Sierra Leone announces Ebola curfew
item.description: A three-day curfew will come into force across parts of Sierra Leone next week to try and contain the Ebola crisis, a health official says.

item.title: Japan man held for US embassy threat
item.description: Japanese police arrest a man for threats made against the US embassy, following multiple death threats against Ambassador Caroline Kennedy.

item.title: EU links Russia sanctions to truce
item.description: EU leaders agree to keep sanctions on Russia over its role in the Ukraine conflict until the end of 2015 at the earliest, tying them to a truce deal.

item.title: Mexican man freed after 23 years
item.description: A Mexican-American man convicted for the 1992 murder of his sister and brother-in-law is freed after a court rules he confessed under torture.

item.title: Air raid on Yemen president's palace
item.description: Warplanes target the palace used by Yemen's President Abdrabbuh Mansour Hadi in Aden, following deadly clashes at the city's airport.

item.title: US fond of royals, Obama tells prince
item.description: US President Barack Obama tells the Prince of Wales of the "fondness" of American people for the Royal Family.

item.title: UKIP suspends MEP over finance claim
item.description: UKIP suspends MEP and general election candidate Janice Atkinson "following allegations of a serious financial nature" and launches an inquiry.

item.title: Multi-billion pound plans for rail
item.description: Plans to overhaul transport across the North of England, including multi-billion pound rail schemes, are being laid out by the government later.

item.title: Sex crime suspects 'need anonymity'
item.description: The names of sex offence suspects in England and Wales should not be made public unless they are charged, a cross-party group of MPs says.

item.title: Mental health budgets 'cut by 8%'
item.description: Mental health trusts in England have had their budgets cut by more than 8% in real terms over the course of this parliament, research suggests.

item.title: In pictures: Liminal Space
item.description: Sarah Lucy Brown's photographs of the Suffolk coastline.

item.title: Ruskin's daguerreotypes
item.description: A new book charts the discovery of daguerreotypes taken by the 19th Century critic John Ruskin.

item.title: Day in pictures: 19 March 2015
item.description: Images from around the world: 18 March

item.title: Northern Lights illuminate UK skies
item.description: Readers' images of the Aurora Borealis

item.title: Chung Ling Soo posters on sale
item.description: Vintage posters on sale

item.title: Ka-Boom at Format
item.description: Explosions on show at Format festival

item.title: Day in pictures: 18 March 2015
item.description: Images from around the world: 18 March

item.title: In pictures: A new vision of London
item.description: A new vision of London

item.title: Hunting for Prince's vault
item.description: Does the pop enigma have a vault full of unreleased recordings?

item.title: Quiz of the week's news
item.description: Which star's journey to Hollywood began in Ramsey Street?

item.title: The new rise of biometric banking
item.description: The rise and rise of biometric banking

item.title: Saudi Arabia's new desert megacity
item.description: What will Saudi Arabia's new billion-dollar metropolis be like?

item.title: Acapulco struggles to shed violent image
item.description: Acapulco goes from Hollywood resort to crime hotspot

item.title: The mystery of Myanmar's missing umbrella
item.description: Why did an umbrella disappear from an official Myanmar photo?

item.title: Hydrogen, hydrogen everywhere...
item.description: How hydrogen could help decarbonise the world

item.title: Football gives New Yorkers its best pitch
item.description: A new franchise hopes to woo New York's sports fans
